results.title: A Haunted school
results.brief_description:
A short created by a student for the 2004 ACMI Diegesis secondary school media festival.
This moving picture describes bizarre events at a school. A girl goes missing and two detectives set out to find her. Once in the school they turn into students and are horrified when they experience ghostly sightings of the victim. They suffer mortal wounds and turn on each other as they are scared out of their wits. Finally they themselves become possessed and are forever trapped at the school, never to escape.

results.title: The Circle = Dayereh = Il Cerchio [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Jafar Panahi, Lumière & Co., Mikado Film Srl (Rome) and Jafar Panahi Film Productions
results.brief_description: From Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi (The White balloon), comes The Circle” a tale of female oppression in modern day Iran. “The Circle opens in a hospital maternity ward where a woman has just given birth. Her mother is horrified by the catastrophic outcome - its a girl. She had been assured (via ultrasound) that it would be a boy and laments the fact that a divorce will ensue and her daughter will be shamed. This opening sequence reflects the status of women in Iran, as unwanted, second-class citizens without rights or a voice in society. “The Circle” tells the stories of several women in a city over the course of one day and night. Simple acts of buying a bus ticket or smoking a cigarette in public are denied to women and are punishable by law. The women of the film, in constant danger of imprisonment and harassment, are shunned by their families and seek refuge with each other. Panahi adopts a documentary style for this feature film, as street noise fills the soundtrack and the camera follows the characters around, almost hounding them. “The Circle” was banned in Iran due to its controversial subject matter. In Farsi with English subtitles. (Awards: Winner of the Golden Lion, Best Film at the 2000 Venice Film Festival)

results.title: The Century of cinema: Japan and Korea
results.creator_credit: Jang Sun-Woo, Nagisa Oshima, Park Ki-Yong, Eiko Oshima and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
‘Nagisa Oshima’s 100 Years of Japanese Cinema’ is a fascinating personal journey through the history of Japanese film-making which moves from the end of the 19th century through to the mid-90s. A rare chance to see stills and excerpts from classic films made in Japan. Oshima comments on his own films as well as the Japanese film industry and its relationship to the country’s political and social changes. Films by great Japanese directors from Muzoguchi, Ozu, Kurosawa, ‘Beat’ Takeshi Kitano, Manga films and Japanese documentary makers are all discussed. ‘The Cinema On The Road’ is a wonderful documentary which uses the road movie genre as a device to explore the history and current contexts of Korean Cinema. With interesting footage of the Korean landscape and cities, as well as interviews with directors and excerpts and stills from films, this is a fascinating insight into a national cinema which is rarely seen. Both documentaries are in English with interviews and film excerpts in Japanese and Korean with English subtitles.

results.title: The Century of cinema. Volume 1 (UK, Ireland, Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
White fellas dreaming. Written and directed by George Miller. Produced by George Miller and Doug Mitchell. 1996. Miller presents an entertaining journey through Australian cinema. Cinema is discussed in relation to the changing nature of society and how Australians have constructed and deconstructed a national cinema through celluloid. A must see for anyone interested in Australian cinema heritage. “Cinema of unease. A personal journey by Sam Neill”. Written and directed by Sam Neill and Judy Rymer. Produced by Paula Jalfon and Grant Campbell. 1995. New Zealand cinema is a recent addition to the realm of national cinema, experiencing a significant growth in the previous two decades. Neill visits the land he migrated to and his experience as a performer and a viewer. “Typically British”. Directed by Mike Dibb and Stephen Frears, produced by Colin MacCabe. Frears explores the notion of the incompatibility of ‘British’ and ‘cinema’ in a personal way to present the outstanding films and film-makers of Britain.

results.title: The Circle
results.creator_credit: Mort Ransen, John Kemeny and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Produced in 1967, this black and white film is an inmate’s view of Daytop, a drug treatment center on Staten Island, New York, where addicts learn to get along without drugs. Uncompromising, often brutal group therapy sessions are designed to shake loose the excuses a victim makes for himself. The people and situations shown are authentic; only one actor was employed. The results obtained at Daytop are regarded by some psychiatrists as a breakthrough. Cast: Don Francks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mort Ransen, John Kemeny and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: End of the Line
results.brief_description: A short created by a student for the 2004 ACMI Diegesis secondary school media festival. Fleeing from town, a small child finds himself hiding in a seemingly deserted railway station. One day he is crossing the tracks when a train come hurtling towards him. A beautifully photographed film, imbued with feelings of isolation and loneliness.

results.title: The century of cinema. Volume 2 (USA)
results.creator_credit: Michael Henry Wilson, Martin Scorsese, Florence Dauman and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
Scorsese’s enthusiasm for his country’s film history is infectious and it permeates this second volume of the Century of Cinema. Divided into three sections, “A Personal Journey with Martin Scorsese through American cinema” doesn’t attempt to be objective or all inclusive. Instead Scorsese leads us through a fascinating tour of American cinema, conjuring interesting connections and unearthing lesser known gems. Includes interviews with Gregory Peck, Clint Eastwood, Billy Wilder, John Ford, King Vidor, Howard Hawks, Francis Coppola, Brian De Palma, Fritz Lang, Andre de Toth, Douglas Sirk, Nicholas Ray, Samuel Fuller, Orson Welles, Elia Kazan, Arthur Penn and John Cassavetes.

results.title: The Cider House rules
results.creator_credit: Lasse Hallstrom, Richard Gladstein, Miramax Films and Film Colony
results.brief_description: John Irving won an Academy Award for his script to the film which is based on his acclaimed novel of the same name. Set in the lush green landscape of mid-century North East United States, ‘The Cider House rules’ stars Tobey McGuire as Homer, a bright young man who has spent his whole life in St. Cloud’s Orphanage. The institution’s doctor and leader, Wilbur Lynch (Michael Caine), wants Homer to take over his duties in the orphanage. But Homer wants to see more of the world and to experience life outside the safety of St. Clouds. He goes on the road and begins work as a farm-hand in an apple orchard. There he experiences love for the first time, but he is also introduced to the harsh realities of life. Witnessing incest and betrayal for the first time in his life, Homer has to rethink his self-righteous beliefs about single motherhood, adoption and abortion. Though the film deals with controversial subjects and themes, it is a revisionist piece of filmmaking. The sharp lyrical cinematography is by Oliver Stapelton, while Irving’s script and Hallstrom’s direction is classical in structure. But though its mise-en-scene may be nostalgic, in suggesting the darker forces at play in the social order of post-World War II North America, ‘The Cider House rules’ never allows its emotional resonances to slip into sentimentality. The cast is uniformally excellent and Michael Caine won an Academy Award for his performance.

But Homer wants to see more of the world and to experience life outside the safety of St. Clouds. He goes on the road and begins work as a farm-hand in an apple orchard. There he experiences love for the first time, but he is also introduced to the harsh realities of life. Witnessing incest and betrayal for the first time in his life, Homer has to rethink his self-righteous beliefs about single motherhood, adoption and abortion. Though the film deals with controversial subjects and themes, it is a revisionist piece of filmmaking. The sharp lyrical cinematography is by Oliver Stapelton, while Irving’s script and Hallstrom’s direction is classical in structure. But though its mise-en-scene may be nostalgic, in suggesting the darker forces at play in the social order of post-World War II North America, ‘The Cider House rules’ never allows its emotional resonances to slip into sentimentality. The cast is uniformally excellent and Michael Caine won an Academy Award for his performance.

results.title: The Christmas tree
results.brief_description: This is a traditional Ukrainian folktale, based on a story by Michaelo Kochubinsky, set in the 19th century. The story concerns eleven year old Ivanko, his parents, a mysterious old man and the “special” Christmas tree that tests the family’s faith and draws them together.
